blocks.value: Simon is most noted in Scripture for being called "the Zealot." This indicates that at one time he may have been a member of the Zealots, a radical Jewish party. The Zealots were known to be nationalistic rebels who constantly fought for independence and freedom for the Jews. They despised that the Romans ruled and controlled the Jews.

Little is known about Simon after the Ascension of Jesus, but it is believed he preached in Egypt and then went to Persia with St. Jude, where he is reported to have suffered martyrdom. Both Apostles, Simon and Jude, are considered patrons of lost causes and desperate situations.
